column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
I was surprised I passed the exam.
I didn't expect {{c1::to pass}} the exam.
column4: to pass / that I pass / passing / pass

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
Did you manage to solve the problem?
Did you succeed {{c1::in solving}} the problem?
column4: on solving / in solving / you solved / to solve

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
I don't read newspapers any more.
I've given up {{c1::reading}} newspapers.
column4: read / reading / to read / that I read

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
I'd prefer not to go out tonight.
I'd rather {{c1::not go out}} tonight.
column4: not go out / I don't go out / not going out / not to go out

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
He finds it difficult to sleep at night.
He has trouble {{c1::sleeping}} at night.
column4: sleep / sleeping / for sleeping / to sleep

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
Shall I phone you this evening?
Do you want {{c1::me to phone}} you this evening?
column4: me phone / me phoning / me to phone / that I phone

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
Nobody saw me come in.
I came in without {{c1::being seen}}.
column4: anybody see me / been seen / to be seen / being seen

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
They said I was a cheat.
I was accused {{c1::of cheating}}.
column4: for cheating / of cheating / to cheat / to have cheated

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
It will be good to see them again.
I'm looking forward {{c1::to seeing}} them again.
column4: seeing / to see / to seeing / that I see

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
What do you think I should do?
What do you advise me {{c1::to do}}?
column4: to do / doing / do / that I do

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
It's a pity I couldn't go out with you last night.
I'd like {{c1::to have gone}} out with you last night.
column4: to go / that I went / to have gone / having gone

column2: Complete the second sentence so that it means the same as the first one.
column3:
I wish I'd taken your advice.
I regret {{c1::not taking}} your advice.
column4: I don't take / not to take / not taking / I not taking
